reviews.review_msg: He's knowledgeable and kind but wow. He is so disorganized. 2/4 assignments were released two weeks late, but don't worry, we got a 2 day extension. The last assignment was released incomplete with errors, and he was MIA on the discussion board so we were screwed if we had questions. The assignments weren't graded until after the final passed. Bad

Don't listen to all these haters, this guy just may be the GOAT. Explains the slides very well and is always open to questions. While slightly disorganized, he never made me feel cheated or treated unfairly. Steven is clearly very intelligent and knowledgeable and it shows. Great guy. 10/10

The course is really difficult material-wise and a big jump compared to most courses at SFU. There is some disconect between the level Dr. Li expects students to be at vs. what the average student, so it can be hard to follow lectures. Final was super hard (avg. was < 50), but the curve was very generous and class avg was a B. I learned a ton

Prof does practically no examples of formulas in class and just over teaches theory. Has a boring voice and only gets some attendance because of his class quiz participation. Extremely difficult assignments and final had to get scaled.

A strike disrupted this semester, leading to a two-week lecture gap and a challenging final exam. The professor wrapped up the intense material in the last two weeks(make up for the gap) with limited practice or examples. To succeed, students had to comprehend theories derived from these equations for the extensive 35-page finals.

No textbook for non-review part of the course; prof was regularly late for classes and made us stay overtime. The material is very difficult (all math, virtually no coding). Going to lectures does not help at all - they mostly consist of "take this and that.. you know.. right? hm, well, ok moving on". So be prepared to study everything on your own.
